docs.abstract: New productions of “The Merchant of Venice” and “Black No More” aim to reflect our current racial politics. The results are uneven.
docs.snippet: New productions of “The Merchant of Venice” and “Black No More” aim to reflect our current racial politics. The results are uneven.
docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent weekend, I eagerly set out to see two new productions that prominently center Blackness: the director Arin Arbus’s adaptation of Shakespeare’s “The Merchant of Venice” and “Black No More,” a new musical with a starry creative team that was inspired by a satirical 1931 novel about race in America.

headline.main: The Past Pushes Back in 2 Shows With Contemporary Blackness in Mind
headline.print_headline: The Past Knows How to Push Back

docs.abstract: A task force in charge of the state’s reparations effort, the first in the nation, is struggling to decide which Black Californians should receive payments.
docs.snippet: A task force in charge of the state’s reparations effort, the first in the nation, is struggling to decide which Black Californians should receive payments.
docs.lead_paragraph: If California were to provide reparations for Black residents, who exactly should qualify for the payments?

headline.main: Who Should Get Reparations in California?

docs.abstract: Watching the Supreme Court nominee was a major moment, but her treatment by Republican senators felt all too familiar. “Every Black woman speaks that language,” one woman said.
docs.snippet: Watching the Supreme Court nominee was a major moment, but her treatment by Republican senators felt all too familiar. “Every Black woman speaks that language,” one woman said.
docs.lead_paragraph: Jordan Simpson, a 25-year-old aspiring lawyer in Valdosta, Ga., was excited to watch the Senate confirmation hearing for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, until Senator Ted Cruz’s line of questioning made her feel something else: discouraged.

headline.main: How Black Women Saw Ketanji Brown Jackson’s Confirmation Hearing
headline.print_headline: For Black Women Watching the Hearings, Pride Overlapped With Pain

byline.original: By Patricia Mazzei, Tariro Mzezewa and Jill Cowan

docs.abstract: For her 2013 debut novel, Bulawayo was the first Black woman from Africa to become a finalist for the Booker Prize. Her new novel, “Glory,” is a story about a nation on the cusp of revolution.
docs.snippet: For her 2013 debut novel, Bulawayo was the first Black woman from Africa to become a finalist for the Booker Prize. Her new novel, “Glory,” is a story about a nation on the cusp of revolution.
docs.lead_paragraph: Like many of her compatriots, NoViolet Bulawayo once thought Robert Mugabe would rule Zimbabwe forever.

headline.main: NoViolet Bulawayo Believes Freedom Begins With Imagination
headline.print_headline: People on the Margins, Put Center Stage

docs.abstract: Mr. Renaud’s final assignment was documenting refugees fleeing across bridges in Irpin, Ukraine.
docs.snippet: Mr. Renaud’s final assignment was documenting refugees fleeing across bridges in Irpin, Ukraine.
docs.lead_paragraph: When Brent Renaud, an award-winning American filmmaker and journalist, was killed in Ukraine on Sunday, he was there to do what he had done throughout his career: bear witness to the world’s most dangerous stories.

headline.main: Brent Renaud, an American filmmaker killed in Ukraine, captured the human toll of war.

docs.abstract: This is a man on the grandest of missions: to save this country from itself, to insist that morality ought to decide policy.
docs.snippet: This is a man on the grandest of missions: to save this country from itself, to insist that morality ought to decide policy.
docs.lead_paragraph: The Rev. William Barber II is a large man, but bent. He walks with a cane, with his helper nearby, placing each step with deliberation to make sure that his footing is sure.

docs.abstract: With violent crime surging, Mayor Eric Adams is testing how much policing a changed New York City will tolerate.
docs.snippet: With violent crime surging, Mayor Eric Adams is testing how much policing a changed New York City will tolerate.
docs.lead_paragraph: In Mayor Eric Adams’s first three months in office, New York City has been marred by shootings and hate crimes, a fatal subway shoving in Times Square and other high-profile killings. Now, the mayor is testing just how much a liberal city is willing to empower its police.

headline.main: As Adams Toughens on Crime, Some Fear a Return to ’90s Era Policing

byline.original: By Katie Glueck and Ashley Southall

docs.abstract: Mark Miles, a Black officer with the Maryland-National Capital Park Police, says in a lawsuit that his white supervisor and other officers made hateful comments in a work-related text chain.
docs.snippet: Mark Miles, a Black officer with the Maryland-National Capital Park Police, says in a lawsuit that his white supervisor and other officers made hateful comments in a work-related text chain.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a series of text messages, a white supervisor and other police officers in Montgomery County, Md., talked about preparing for a “race war,” and expressed hope that Black Lives Matter protesters would be killed, according to a federal lawsuit filed this week by a Black colleague.

headline.main: Officers Said They Hoped Black Lives Matter Protesters Would Die, Suit Says

docs.abstract: Don’t feel guilty about seeking relief in a game.
docs.snippet: Don’t feel guilty about seeking relief in a game.
docs.lead_paragraph: As I sit writing in a quiet part of my apartment building, I can see two televisions. One is playing CNN. Jake Tapper is asking a reporter how victims of the opioid crisis confronted the Sackler family, which owns Purdue Pharma, at a hearing on Thursday. Earlier, the network focused on images from the war in Ukraine — bloodied victims of bombings, bodies buried in mass graves, buildings on fire.

headline.main: The Comfort of Sports During Difficult Times

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students will read about a new musical that explores women’s fight for the right to vote, listen to the songs and create a poster for their own possible theater production.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students will read about a new musical that explores women’s fight for the right to vote, listen to the songs and create a poster for their own possible theater production.
docs.lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Friendship, Betrayal and the Fight: ‘Suffs’ Tells the Suffragist Tale in Song”  by Jennifer Schuessler

headline.main: Lesson of the Day: ‘Friendship, Betrayal and the Fight: “Suffs” Tells the Suffragist Tale in Song’
